sen.j: 政教社（せいきょうしゃ）は、計１３名を同人として設立された言論団体・出版社である。
sen.e: Seikyo-sha is an opinion group and publishing house, which was established with a total of thirteen people as a Dojin (coterie).

sen.j: 1907年1月、陸羯南の発行していた新聞日本 (新聞)が経営難に陥り、陸羯南が社長を退いたことで社員の多くが新社長・伊藤欽亮の経営第一主義に反発し、羯南の盟友であった三宅の『日本人』に合流。
sen.e: In January 1907, Shinbun Nihon (a newspaper) fell into economic difficulties and when Katsunan KUGA, the President resigned, many of the employees revolted against the profit-chasing style of Kinsuke ITO, the new President, and joined "Nihonjin" edited by MIYAKE, who was a close friend of Katsunan.

sen.j: 政教社の『日本及び日本人』は、徳富蘇峰の民友社が発行した『国民の友』と対抗し、言論界を二分化するほどの人気を博した。
sen.e: "Nihon oyobi Nihonjin" of Seikyo-sha competed with "Kokumin-no tomo (friend of the people)" published by Soho TOKUTOMI's Minyu-sha, and the two were so popular as to split the opinion world into two.

sen.j: 民友社は政府主導の鹿鳴館文化を貴族的欧化であると見なし、平民的欧化主義の立場から政府批判を繰り返していた。
sen.e: Minyu-sha saw the Rokumeikan-bunka Culture, led by the government, as an aristocratic Europeanism and continued to criticize the government from the position of the commoners' Europeanism.

sen.j: 井上円了による東洋大学（前述の哲学館（1887年創立）の後身）は、男子専門だった私立学校で、日本で初めて女子の入学を許可（1916年）し、さらに女性教員を世に送り出すなどした、最初の共学の私立大学である。
sen.e: Toyo University (successor of the above-mentioned Tetsugakukan, built in 1887) established by Enryo INOUE, was a boys-only private school but became the first school in Japan to admit girls (in 1916), raised women teachers and was the first co-ed private university in Japan.

Toyo University (successor of the above-mentioned Tetsugakukan, built in 1887) established by Enryo INOUE, was a boys-only private school that became Japan's first coeducational private university; the school admitted girls (in 1916) for the first time in Japan and also produced women teachers.

sen.j: また、島地黙雷による女子文芸学舎（現在の千代田女学園の前身、1888年創立）は、仏教を基調とする女子教育の先駆であり、棚橋一郎が創立した東京高等女学校（現在の東京女子学園中学校・高等学校の前身、1903年創立）は、東京府下で最初の、普通科の私立高等女学校である。
sen.e: Joshi Bungei Gakusha (established in 1888 and was the predecessor of the Chiyoda Jogakuen) which was created by Mokurai SHIMAJI, was the pioneer in women's education based on Buddhist teachings, and the Tokyo Koto Jogakko (built in 1903 and was the predecessor of Tokyo Joshigakuen Junior High Schools) built by Ichiro TANAHASHI was the first private women's school for comprehensive higher education in the Tokyo prefecture.

sen.j: 関東大震災後の改組問題で雪嶺が退社したのちの政教社は、五百木良三・三井甲之ら日本主義者によって牛耳られるようになり、4月に解散した。
sen.e: When Setsurei resigned from Seikyo-sha over reorganization after the Great Kanto Earthquake, it began to be dominated by nationalists such as Ryozo IOGI and Koshi MITSUI, and was finally dissolved in April.
